tit.e: Yamato no kodo (the ancient paths in Yamato Province)

sen.e: Yamato no kodo stands for the ancient paths in Japan that were constructed in Yamato Province.

sen.j: 奈良盆地の東、平地と山地の間を縫うように南北に通る道。
sen.e: Some of the roads are located in the eastern area of the Nara Basin, and run north and south, threading along flat lands among mountains.

sen.j: 山の辺の道
sen.e: Yamanobe-no-michi Road
Yamanobe-no-michi Road
Yamanobe-no-michi Road

sen.j: 奈良盆地の中央より東を南北に平行する三本の縦貫道。
sen.e: Yamanobe-no-michi Road are three parallel roads running in a north-south direction in the eastern areas of the Nara Basin.
Yamanobe-no-michi Road are three parallel roads running in a north-south direction in the eastern areas of the Nara Basin.

sen.j: 上街道 (上ツ道)（かみつみち）、中ツ道（なかつみち）、中街道 (下ツ道)（しもつみち）。
sen.e: They are called the Kami Kaido (Kamitsu Michi), Nakatsu Michi and the Naka Kaido (Shimotsu Michi).
They are called the Kami-kaido (Kamitsu Michi), Nakatsu Michi and the Naka-kaido (Shimotsu Michi).

sen.e: They are called the Kami-kaido (Kamitsu Michi), Nakatsu Michi and the Naka-kaido (Shimotsu Michi).

sen.j: また、これを「大和三道」ともいう。
sen.e: They are also known as the three ancient paths of Yamato.
They are also known as the three ancient paths of Yamato.

sen.j: 奈良盆地の中央と南部を東西に平行する二本の横断道。
sen.e: Others include two parallel roads running in an east-west direction in the middle and the southern parts of the Nara Basin.
Others include two parallel roads running in an east-west direction in the middle and the southern parts of the Nara Basin.

sen.j: 横大路 (奈良県)（よこおおじ）、北の横大路
sen.e: They are called Yokooji (Nara Prefecture) and Kita no Yoko-oji.
They are called Yokooji (Nara Prefecture) and Kita no Yoko-oji.

sen.j: 奈良盆地の中央部を斜め（北北西-南南東方向）に通る道。
sen.e: There is another road running obliquely in the direction of north-northwest to south-southeast.
There is another road running obliquely in the direction of north-northwest to south-southeast.

sen.j: 法隆寺街道（すじかいみち）
sen.e: It is called the Sujikaimichi Road.
sen.cmt: 法隆寺街道（すじかいみち）とあるのはリンク先の表示です。ウェブ上では「筋違道（すじかいみち）」となっているので、このように訳出しました。
sen.e: It is called the Sujikaimichi Road.
It is called the Sujikaimichi Road.

tit.j: 上ツ道・中ツ道・下ツ道概要
tit.e: Summary of Kamitsu Michi, Nakatsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi
Summary of Kamitsu Michi, Nakatsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi
Summary of Kamitsu Michi, Nakatsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi

sen.j: 南北にまっすぐ通る三道は、ほぼ4里（一里＝531メートル、四里で約2120m）の等間隔をなしており、東から順に上ツ道、中ツ道、下ツ道と平行に並んでいる。
sen.e: The three roads stretch straight in a north-south direction in equal intervals of about 2,120m, and run parallel to each other in the order of Kamitsu Michi, Nakatsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi from east to west.

The three roads stretch straight in a north-south direction in equal intervals of about 2,120m, and run parallel to each other in the order of Kamitsu Michi, Nakatsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi from east to west.

The three roads stretch straight in a north-south direction in equal intervals of about 2,120m, and run parallel to each other in the order of Kamitsu Michi, Nakatsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi from east to west.

sen.j: 現在でも形跡が残っている箇所も多く存在する。
sen.e: There are many traces remaining until today.
There are many traces remaining until today.
There are many traces remaining until today.

sen.j: 三道の敷設年代については、『日本書紀』孝徳天皇の白雉4年(653)六月条に「処処の大道を脩治（つく）る」とあることなどを勘案して七世紀中ば頃に敷設されたと推定されている。
sen.e: The date of construction is estimated to be in the mid 7th century, considering the description in the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) at the part of June 653 in the era of the Emperor Kotoku, saying that they constructed big roads in several places.

The date of construction is estimated to be in the mid 7th century, considering the description in the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) at the part of June 653 in the era of the Emperor Kotoku, saying that they constructed big roads in several places.
sen.cmt: 全角の"を半角にしました。
sen.e: The date of construction is estimated to be in the mid 7th century, considering the description in the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) at the part of June 653 in the era of the Emperor Kotoku, saying that they constructed big roads in several places.

sen.j: また、『日本書紀』によれば、壬申の乱の奈良盆地での戦闘記事には、すでにこの三道の名が見えるので、天武天皇朝以前には完成していたことが知られる。
sen.e: The three roads appear in the articles of the "Nihon Shoki" about battles at Jinshin War in the Nara Basin, which means the roads had already been constructed before the era of the Emperor Tenmu.
The three roads appear in the articles of the "Nihon Shoki" about battles at Jinshin War in the Nara Basin, which means the roads had already been constructed before the era of the Emperor Tenmu.
sen.cmt: 全角の"を半角にしました。
sen.e: The three roads appear in the articles of the "Nihon Shoki" about battles at Jinshin War in the Nara Basin, which means the roads had already been constructed before the era of the Emperor Tenmu.

sen.j: 三道の目的については、よく分かっていない。
sen.e: The purpose of constructing these roads is unclear.
The purpose of constructing these roads is unclear.
The purpose of constructing these roads is unclear.

sen.j: 七世紀に飛鳥盆地や周辺の丘陵部で宮殿・寺院・貴族の邸宅の造営などが相次いで行われた。
sen.e: In the 7th century, there was a rush of construction of palaces, temples and residences of the nobles on the hills of Asuka Basin and its surrounding areas.
In the 7th century, there was a rush of construction of palaces, temples and residences of the nobles on the hills of Asuka Basin and its surrounding areas.
In the 7th century, there was a rush of construction of palaces, temples and residences of the nobles on the hills of Asuka Basin and its surrounding areas.

sen.j: とりわけ斉明朝には、巨大な建築物や山をも取り込んで石造の巨大施設が作られていた。
sen.e: Especially in the era governed by Saimei, a huge stone-made facility was constructed, made up of large stone buildings and mountains.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Especially in the era governed by Saimei, a huge stone-made facility was constructed, made up of large stone buildings and mountains.
Especially in the era governed by Saimei, a huge stone-made facility was constructed, made up of large stone buildings and mountains.

sen.j: その材料の運搬のための道路であるとも考えられる。
sen.e: These roads may have been laid with the purpose of carrying materials for this construction.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These roads may have been laid with the purpose of carrying materials for this construction.
These roads may have been laid with the purpose of carrying materials for this construction.

sen.j: また、壬申の等乱でこの三道が効果的によく用いられているところから、軍事用に作られたのではないか、とも推測されている。
sen.e: Others suppose that these roads were constructed for military purposes, since the roads played important roles in battles including Jinshin War.
Others suppose that these roads were constructed for military purposes, since the roads played important roles in battles including Jinshin War.
Others suppose that these roads were constructed for military purposes, since the roads played important roles in battles including Jinshin War.

sen.j: 上ツ道は桜井市から奈良盆地東端の山沿いを北上して、天理市を経て奈良市中部（猿沢池）に至る古道。
sen.e: Kamitsu Michi is an ancient road that starts from Sakurai City, goes up north along mountains at the eastern edge of the Nara Basin, runs through Tenri City and reaches the Sarusawa-ike Pond in the middle of Nara City.

Kamitsu Michi is an ancient road that starts from Sakurai City, goes up north along mountains at the eastern edge of the Nara Basin, runs through Tenri City and reaches the Sarusawa-ike Pond in the middle of Nara City.

Kamitsu Michi is an ancient road that starts from Sakurai City, goes up north along mountains at the eastern edge of the Nara Basin, runs through Tenri City and reaches the Sarusawa-ike Pond in the middle of Nara City.

sen.j: 古墳時代には物部氏の西山古墳と南では箸墓古墳を結んでいたのではないか。
sen.e: There is a supposition that this road connected Nishiyama Tumulus of the Mononobe Clan and Hashihaka Tumulus in the south during the Kofun period (tumulus period).
There is a supposition that this road connected Nishiyama Tumulus of the Mononobe clan and Hashihaka Tumulus in the south during the Kofun period (tumulus period).
There is a supposition that this road connected Nishiyama Tumulus of the Mononobe clan and Hashihaka Tumulus in the south during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

sen.j: 近世では上街道と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In recent times, the road was called the Kami Kaido.
In recent times, the road was called the Kami-kaido.
sen.cmt: ハイフン補足しました。kaido 小文字にしました。
sen.e: In recent times, the road was called the Kami-kaido.

sen.j: 現在では伊勢街道、長谷街道などとよばれている。
sen.e: Now it is called under the names of Ise-Kaido Road and Hase-Kaido Road.
Now it is called under the names of Ise-kaido Road and Hase-kaido Road.
sen.cmt: kaido 小文字にしました。
sen.e: Now it is called under the names of Ise-kaido Road and Hase-kaido Road.

sen.j: 南は桜井市仁王堂で横大路 (奈良県)と交わり、更にその先は山田道を経て飛鳥へと通じている。
sen.e: At the southern end, the road crosses with Yokooji (Nara Prefecture) and connects to Yamada-michi Road that leads to Asuka.
At the southern end, the road crosses with Yokooji (Nara Prefecture) and connects to Yamada-michi Road that leads to Asuka.
At the southern end, the road crosses with Yokooji (Nara Prefecture) and connects to Yamada-michi Road that leads to Asuka.

sen.j: また、櫟本（天理市）で「北の横大路」と交わっている。
sen.e: The road crosses with Kita no Yoko-oji at Ichinomoto (Tenri City).
The road crosses with Kita no Yoko-oji at Ichinomoto (Tenri City).
The road crosses with Kita no Yoko-oji at Ichinomoto (Tenri City).

sen.j: 中ツ道は、上ツ道と下ツ道の間約2.1kmの所を平行して通る。
sen.e: Nakatsu Michi runs parallel to and between Kamitsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi with intervals of about 2.1km each.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Nakatsu Michi runs parallel to and between Kamitsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi with intervals of about 2.1km each.
Nakatsu Michi runs parallel to and between Kamitsu Michi and Shimotsu Michi with intervals of about 2.1km each.

sen.j: 南は藤原京の東京極をなし、北ではのちの平城京の東京極となった。
sen.e: The southern end formed the Higashikyogoku (eastern end) of Fujiwara-kyo, and the northern end formed the Higashikyogoku of Heijo-kyo later.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処；「東京極」定訳不明ですが、意味を説明しないと通らないと考え、訳出しています。
sen.e: The southern end formed the Higashikyogoku (eastern end) of Fujiwara-kyo, and the northern end formed the Higashikyogoku of Heijo-kyo later.
The southern end formed the Higashikyogoku (eastern end) of Fujiwara-kyo, and the northern end formed the Higashikyogoku of Heijo-kyo later.

sen.j: 橿原市の天香具山北麓から奈良市北之庄町に至る直線道である。
sen.e: This is a straight road stretching from the north foot of Amanokaguyama hill to Kitanosho-cho, Nara City.
This is a straight road stretching from the north foot of Amanokaguyama hill to Kitanosho-cho, Nara City.
This is a straight road stretching from the north foot of Amanokaguyama hill to Kitanosho-cho, Nara City.

sen.j: 更に南は香具山を迂回し橘寺へ至るため、近世は橘街道と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Since the southern part goes around the Kaguyama hill and leads to Tachibana—dera Temple, the road was called Tachibana Kaido in recent times.
Since the southern part goes around the Kaguyama hill and leads to Tachibana—dera Temple, the road was called Tachibana-kaido in recent times.
sen.cmt: ハイフン補足しました。kaido 小文字にしました。
sen.e: Since the southern part goes around the Kaguyama hill and leads to Tachibana—dera Temple, the road was called Tachibana-kaido in recent times.

sen.j: 中ツ道また飛鳥の中心部を通っている。
sen.e: Nakatsu Michi also penetrates the center of Asuka.
sen.cmt: 中ツ道「は」また、として訳しています。
sen.e: Nakatsu Michi also penetrates the center of Asuka.
Nakatsu Michi also penetrates the center of Asuka.

sen.j: 南の延長線上に「ミハ山」があり、『万葉集』(13-3230)にも詠まれている。
sen.e: If extended southward, this road leads to 'Mt. Miha', which is described in a poem in the "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves; 13-3230).
If extended southward, this road leads to 'Mt. Miha,' which is described in a poem in the "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves; 13-3230).
sen.cmt: 全角の”、’を半角にしましたコンマの位置を訂正しました。
sen.e: If extended southward, this road leads to 'Mt. Miha,' which is described in a poem in the "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves; 13-3230).

sen.j: その「ミワ山」が「神名火山」で、「神岳」である吉野に通ずる道しるべであるかも知れない。
sen.e: The 'Mt. Miwa' can be considered as 'Kannabiyama' (the mountain where gods live), and a guide for Yoshino known as 'Kamioka.'
sen.cmt: 「神名火山」正式な読み方不明（かんなびやま、かんなびさん等）。意味を付けて訳出しています。
sen.e: The 'Mt. Miwa' can be considered as 'Kannabiyama' (the mountain where gods live), and a guide for Yoshino known as 'Kamioka.'
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角にしました
sen.e: The 'Mt. Miwa' can be considered as 'Kannabiyama' (the mountain where gods live), and a guide for Yoshino known as 'Kamioka.'

sen.j: 更に南下すれば芋峠を経て吉野に至る。
sen.e: Going further southbound, the road reaches Yoshino via Imo Pass.
Going further southbound, the road reaches Yoshino via Imo Pass.
Going further southbound, the road reaches Yoshino via Imo Pass.

sen.j: 近江朝廷を脱出した天武天皇は、この中ッ道を通って吉野の嶋宮に入ったと推測されている。
sen.e: It is said that the Emperor Tenmu, after escaping from the Omi Dynasty, went to Shimanomiya (detached palace) in Yoshino via Nakatsu Michi.
It is said that the Emperor Tenmu, after escaping from the Omi Court, went to Shimanomiya (detached palace) in Yoshino via Nakatsu Michi.
It is said that the Emperor Tenmu, after escaping from the Omi Court, went to Shimanomiya (detached palace) in Yoshino via Nakatsu Michi.

sen.j: 平安時代には吉野詣で賑わった。
sen.e: During the Heian period, the road bustled with pilgrims for Yoshino.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During the Heian period, the road bustled with pilgrims for Yoshino.
During the Heian period, the road bustled with pilgrims for Yoshino.

sen.j: 御堂関白記には藤原道長もこの道を経て吉野へ向かったと記されている。
sen.e: According to Mido Kanpakuki (The Diary of FUJIWARA no Michinaga), FUJIWARA no Michinaga also passed this road to visit Yoshino.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to Mido Kanpakuki (The Diary of FUJIWARA no Michinaga), FUJIWARA no Michinaga also passed this road to visit Yoshino.

sen.j: 他の道に比べれば形跡はあまりはっきりと残っておらず、途切れがちな印象である。
sen.e: The traces of this road are unclear and interrupted, compared to those of other roads.
The traces of this road are unclear and interrupted, compared to those of other roads.
The traces of this road are unclear and interrupted, compared to those of other roads.

sen.j: 下ツ道は、藤原京（現・橿原市）の西京極から、奈良盆地の中央を北上し、平城京（現・奈良市）の朱雀大路となる。
sen.e: Shimotsu Michi starts from Fujiwara-kyo (present-day Kashihara City), goes through the middle Nara Basin northbound and becomes Suzaku-oji Street in Heijo-kyo (present-day Nara City).
Shimotsu Michi starts from Fujiwara-kyo (present-day Kashihara City), goes through the middle Nara Basin northbound and becomes Suzaku-oji Street in Heijo-kyo (present-day Nara City).
Shimotsu Michi starts from Fujiwara-kyo (present-day Kashihara City), goes through the middle Nara Basin northbound and becomes Suzaku-oji Street in Heijo-kyo (present-day Nara City).

sen.j: 道幅は、両側にある側溝の中心間で22.7メートルである。
sen.e: The width is 22.7m, as measured between the centers of gutters at each side of the road.
The width is 22.7m, as measured between the centers of gutters at each side of the road.
The width is 22.7m, as measured between the centers of gutters at each side of the road.

sen.j: 橿原市大軽町と五条野町に跨る見瀬丸山古墳の周濠の西端をかすめて南進している。
sen.e: The road goes south, brushing the western end of the moat around the Mise Maruyama Tumulus stretching from Ogaru-cho and Gojono-cho, Kashihara City.
The road goes south, brushing the western end of the moat around the Mise Maruyama Tumulus stretching from Ogaru-cho and Gojono-cho, Kashihara City.
The road goes south, brushing the western end of the moat around the Mise Maruyama Tumulus stretching from Ogaru-cho and Gojono-cho, Kashihara City.

sen.j: 橿原市から天理市にかけては、現在の国道24号線とだいたい合致・平行する。
sen.e: Most of the part from Kashihara City to Tenri City corresponds to or runs parallel to the present-day Route 24.
Most of the part from Kashihara City to Tenri City corresponds to or runs parallel to the present-day Route 24.
Most of the part from Kashihara City to Tenri City corresponds to or runs parallel to the present-day Route 24.

sen.j: 近世には中街道と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: In recent times, the road was called the Naka Kaido.
In recent times, the road was called the Naka-kaido.
sen.cmt: ハイフン補足しました。kaido 小文字にしました。
sen.e: In recent times, the road was called the Naka-kaido.

sen.j: 現在の桜井市の三輪山の南から葛城市の二上山 (奈良県・大阪府)付近まで東西に設置された道 と 斑鳩町の法隆寺付近から天理市の櫟本まで東西に通っていた道がある。
sen.e: There are two Yokooji; one is the road in an east-west direction starting from the southern area of Mt. Miwa in present-day Sakurai City to Mt. Nijo in Katsuragi City (Nara Prefecture and Osaka Prefecture) and the other is the road in an east-west direction starting from around Horyu-ji Temple in Ikaruga Town to Ichinomoto in Tenri City.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There are two Yokooji; one is the road in an east-west direction starting from the southern area of Mt. Miwa in present-day Sakurai City to Mt. Nijo in Katsuragi City (Nara Prefecture and Osaka Prefecture) and the other is the road in an east-west direction starting from around Horyu-ji Temple in Ikaruga Town to Ichinomoto in Tenri City.

There are two Yokooji; one is the road in an east-west direction starting from the southern area of Mt. Miwa in present-day Sakurai City to Mt. Nijo in Katsuragi City (Nara Prefecture and Osaka Prefecture) and the other is the road in an east-west direction starting from around Horyu-ji Temple in Ikaruga Town to Ichinomoto in Tenri City.

sen.j: 通常、横大路とは前者のことを指し、後者は「北の横大路」と区別される。
sen.e: As a general rule, Yokooji refers to the former one, and the latter is called Kita no Yoko-oji.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As a general rule, Yokooji refers to the former one, and the latter is called Kita no Yoko-oji.

sen.j: 法隆寺（斑鳩町）付近から飛鳥（明日香村）へほぼ一直線に結んでいたとされる官道。
sen.e: It is an almost straight kando (a road that is improved, managed and maintained by the Japanese nation) connecting the area around Horyu-ji Temple (Ikaruga Town) and Asuka (Asuka-mura).
It is an almost straight kando (a road that is improved, managed and maintained by the Japanese nation) connecting the area around Horyu-ji Temple (Ikaruga Town) and Asuka (Asuka-mura).

sen.j: 南北から北北西-南南東方向に約20度傾いて設置されているところから、筋違道と呼ばれた。
sen.e: The road was called Sujikaimichi Road (diagonal road) because it was oblique in the north-northwest to the south-southeast direction by about 20 degrees from the north-south line.
The road was called Sujikaimichi Road (diagonal road) because it was oblique in the north-northwest to the south-southeast direction by about 20 degrees from the north-south line.
The road was called Sujikaimichi Road (diagonal road) because it was oblique in the north-northwest to the south-southeast direction by about 20 degrees from the north-south line.

sen.j: 斜行道（しゃこうどう）とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: The road was also called Shakodo Road.
The road was also called Shakodo Road.
The road was also called Shakodo Road.

sen.j: また、聖徳太子が行き来したとされることから、「太子道」とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: Another name of this road is 'Taishimichi,' as Prince Shotoku is supposed to have passed this road.
Another name of this road is 'Taishimichi,' as Prince Shotoku is supposed to have passed this road.
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角にしました。
sen.e: Another name of this road is 'Taishimichi,' as Prince Shotoku is supposed to have passed this road.

sen.j: 奈良盆地の東南にある三輪山のふもとから東北部の若草山に並んでいる春日山のふもとまで、盆地の東端を山々の裾を縫うように通っているのが、山の辺の道（山辺の道、やまのべのみち）である。
sen.e: Yamanobe-no-michi Road threads the skirts of the mountains located in the east end of the Nara Basin, starting from the foot of Mt. Miwa at the southeast of the Basin to the foot of Mt. Kasuga standing by Mt. Wakakusa in the northeast.

Yamanobe-no-michi Road threads the skirts of the mountains located in the east end of the Nara Basin, starting from the foot of Mt. Miwa at the southeast of the Basin to the foot of Mt. Kasuga standing by Mt. Wakakusa in the northeast.

Yamanobe-no-michi Road threads the skirts of the mountains located in the east end of the Nara Basin, starting from the foot of Mt. Miwa at the southeast of the Basin to the foot of Mt. Kasuga standing by Mt. Wakakusa in the northeast.

sen.j: 山辺の道の道程は、その時々の交通事情により少しずつ変化してきている。
sen.e: The route of Yamanobe-no-michi Road has been slightly changing according to the traffic conditions of each era.
The route of Yamanobe-no-michi Road has been slightly changing according to the traffic conditions of each era.
The route of Yamanobe-no-michi Road has been slightly changing according to the traffic conditions of each era.

sen.j: 山辺の道の名称は、『古事記』では、崇神天皇の条「御陵は山辺の道のまがりの岡の上にあり」同じく景行紀には「御陵は山辺の道上にあり」とあり、これらに由来すると思われる。
sen.e: The name of Yamanobe-no-michi Road is supposed to come from the descriptions in the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) at the part of the Emperor Sujin saying that the tumulus was at the Magari hill in Yamanobe-no-michi and the part of Keiko saying that the tumulus was located along Yamanobe-no-michi.

The name of Yamanobe-no-michi Road is supposed to come from the descriptions in the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) at the part of the Emperor Sujin saying that the tumulus was at the Magari hill in Yamanobe-no-michi and the part of Keiko saying that 'the tumulus was located along Yamanobe-no-michi.'
sen.cmt: 全角の”を半角にしました。原文の「」に合せて' 'を補足しました。
sen.e: The name of Yamanobe-no-michi Road is supposed to come from the descriptions in the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) at the part of the Emperor Sujin saying that the tumulus was at the Magari hill in Yamanobe-no-michi and the part of Keiko saying that 'the tumulus was located along Yamanobe-no-michi.'

sen.j: この山の辺の道は、弥生時代後期には、布留遺跡と纏向遺跡を結ぶ道であったとも推測されている。
sen.e: It is also supposed that Yamanobe-no-michi Road connected the Furu Site and the Makimuku Site in late Yayoi period.
It is also supposed that Yamanobe-no-michi Road connected the Furu Site and the Makimuku Site in late Yayoi period.
It is also supposed that Yamanobe-no-michi Road connected the Furu Site and the Makimuku Site in late Yayoi period.

sen.j: 起点
sen.e: Starting point
Starting point
Starting point

sen.j: 現在のその道の起点は、海石榴市（つばいち、椿市つばきのいち）である。
sen.e: In present, the starting point of this road is Tsubaichi (also known as Tsubakinoichi).
In present, the starting point of this road is Tsubaichi (also known as Tsubakinoichi).
In present, the starting point of this road is Tsubaichi (also known as Tsubakinoichi).

sen.j: 古代には、海石榴市の八十（ヤソ）の衢（ちまた）と称されたところで、桜井市粟殿（おおどの）を中心とした地域であった。
sen.e: In ancient times, the place was called Yaso no chimata (the ancient crossroad of Tsubaichi), and was located around the area of Odono, Sakurai City.
In ancient times, the place was called Yaso no chimata (the ancient crossroad of Tsubaichi), and was located around the area of Odono, Sakurai City.
In ancient times, the place was called Yaso no chimata (the ancient crossroad of Tsubaichi), and was located around the area of Odono, Sakurai City.

sen.j: 平安時代中期の926年（延長4）には椿市観音堂付近が起点の地になった。
sen.e: In 926 in the middle of the Heian period, the designated starting point was the area around Tsubakiichi kannon hall.
In 926 in the middle of the Heian period, the designated starting point was the area around Tsubakiichi kannon hall.
In 926 in the middle of the Heian period, the designated starting point was the area around Tsubakiichi kannon hall.

sen.j: この市は、政治の中心が主として奈良盆地の東南部にあった頃、定期的に市が立って栄えた。
sen.e: The place prospered as there were periodic markets at this place when the governmental center was mainly in the southeast area of the Nara Basin.
The place prospered as there were periodic markets at this place when the governmental center was mainly in the southeast area of the Nara Basin.
The place prospered as there were periodic markets at this place when the governmental center was mainly in the southeast area of the Nara Basin.

sen.j: また、初瀬川を下り大和川に出る水運ができあがっていたから河港もでき、水陸交通などの要衝の土地であった。
sen.e: It was also an important place of amphibious traffic, since water transportation from the Hase-gawa River to the Yamato-gawa River and river ports had already been established.
It was also an important place of amphibious traffic, since water transportation from the Hase-gawa River to the Yamato-gawa River and river ports had already been established.
It was also an important place of amphibious traffic, since water transportation from the Hase-gawa River to the Yamato-gawa River and river ports had already been established.

sen.j: その場所は三輪山の南、今の桜井市金屋付近である。
sen.e: The place corresponds to present-day Kanaya in Sakurai City at the south of Mt. Miwa.
The place corresponds to present-day Kanaya in Sakurai City at the south of Mt. Miwa.
The place corresponds to present-day Kanaya in Sakurai City at the south of Mt. Miwa.

sen.j: 推古紀16年（608年）8月の条に「唐の客を海石榴市の衢に迎ふ」とある。
sen.e: In the article of August 608, there is a description saying that they welcomed the envoys from overseas at the crossroad of Tsubaichi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処；来たのは随の人なので、「唐」は国名の唐ではなく「外国」の意味として訳しています。
sen.e: In the article of August 608, there is a description saying that they welcomed the envoys from overseas at the crossroad of Tsubaichi.
In the article of August 608, there is a description saying that they welcomed the envoys from overseas at the crossroad of Tsubaichi.

sen.j: 隋の使者は、初瀬川を船で遡り海石榴市で船を降り、市（衢）そこで出迎えられ、飛鳥の小墾田宮に入京したのであろう。
sen.e: From this, we can suppose that the envoys from the Sui Dynasty took the route via Hase-gawa River by boat, got off at Tsubaichi, got a welcome there and went to Oharida Palace in Asuka.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: From this, we can suppose that the envoys from the Sui Dynasty took the route via Hase-gawa River by boat, got off at Tsubaichi, got a welcome there and went to Oharida Palace in Asuka.
From this, we can suppose that the envoys from the Sui Dynasty took the route via Hase-gawa River by boat, got off at Tsubaichi, got a welcome there and went to Oharida Palace in Asuka.

sen.j: 路傍に「海石榴市観音道」の石の道標があり、少し離れたところに「海石榴市観音堂」がある。
sen.e: There is a stone-made guidepost along the road saying that it was the ancient road of Tsubaichi kannon, and at a short distance is located the Tsubaichi kannon hall.
There is a stone-made guidepost along the road saying that it was the ancient road of Tsubaichi kannon, and at a short distance is located the Tsubaichi kannon hall.
There is a stone-made guidepost along the road saying that it was the ancient road of Tsubaichi kannon, and at a short distance is located the Tsubaichi kannon hall.

sen.j: 金屋の集落を後にして三輪山の山麓を北へ行くと三輪山の神大物主を祭神とする大神神社につく。
sen.e: Leaving the town of Kanaya, one can go northward along the foot of Mt. Miwa to reach the Omiwa-jinja Shrine, where Omononushi the god of Mt. Miwa is enshrined.
Leaving the town of Kanaya, one can go northward along the foot of Mt. Miwa to reach the Omiwa-jinja Shrine, where Omononushi the god of Mt. Miwa is enshrined.
Leaving the town of Kanaya, one can go northward along the foot of Mt. Miwa to reach the Omiwa-jinja Shrine, where Omononushi the god of Mt. Miwa is enshrined.

sen.j: 三輪山信仰は縄文時代または弥生時代まで遡るかも知れない。
sen.e: The Mt. Miwa worship may date back to Jomon period or Yayoi period.
The Mt. Miwa worship may date back to Jomon period or Yayoi period.
The Mt. Miwa worship may date back to Jomon period or Yayoi period.

sen.j: 古墳時代にはいると山麓地帯には全長が200メートルを超える巨大古墳が造られた。
sen.e: In Kofun period, huge tumuli with the length of over 200m were constructed at the foot of mountains.
In Kofun period, huge tumuli with the length of over 200m were constructed at the foot of mountains.
In Kofun period, huge tumuli with the length of over 200m were constructed at the foot of mountains.

sen.j: 『古事記』には、「山の辺の道の勾（まがり）の岡の上（ほとり）に崇神天皇の行燈山古墳（242メートル）が、「山の辺の道の上」に景行天皇の渋谷向山古墳（310メートル）があると記している。
sen.e: The "Kojiki" says that the Andonyama Tumulus (242m) of the Emperor Sujin was located at the Magari hill in Yamanobe-no-michi and the Shibutani Mukoyama Tumulus (310m) of the Emperor Keiko was located along Yamanobe-no-michi.

The "Kojiki" says that the Andonyama Tumulus (242m) of the Emperor Sujin was located at the Magari hill in Yamanobe-no-michi and the Shibutani Mukoyama Tumulus (310m) of the Emperor Keiko was located along Yamanobe-no-michi.
sen.cmt: 全角の”を半角にしました。
sen.e: The "Kojiki" says that the Andonyama Tumulus (242m) of the Emperor Sujin was located at the Magari hill in Yamanobe-no-michi and the Shibutani Mukoyama Tumulus (310m) of the Emperor Keiko was located along Yamanobe-no-michi.

sen.j: 初期ヤマト政権がこの地に誕生したと考えられている。
sen.e: The first Yamato regime is supposed to have started at this place.
The first Yamato regime is supposed to have started at this place.
The first Yamato regime is supposed to have started at this place.

sen.j: このように両天皇の墓が「山の辺の道」の岡にあると『古事記』に記されているところから8世紀の初めにはこの道が出来ており、7世紀の末の藤原京時代にもできあがっていたのではないかと推測できる。
sen.e: Since the "Kojiki" says that tumuli of two emperors are located at the hill of 'Yamanobe-no-michi,' it is supposed that the road had been constructed before early 8th century, or at the end of 7th century in the era of Fujiwara-kyo.

Since the "Kojiki" says that tumuli of two emperors are located at the hill of 'Yamanobe-no-michi,' it is supposed that the road had been constructed before early 8th century, or at the end of 7th century in the era of Fujiwara-kyo.
sen.cmt: 全角の”、’を半角にしました。
sen.e: Since the "Kojiki" says that tumuli of two emperors are located at the hill of 'Yamanobe-no-michi,' it is supposed that the road had been constructed before early 8th century, or at the end of 7th century in the era of Fujiwara-kyo.

sen.j: 現在では、静寂さを取り戻しており、山裾の曲がりくねった道ではあるが、縄文や弥生の時代から、人々によく利用されてきた道であろう。
sen.e: Now the winding road at the foot of mountains is a silent place, but it has long been a popular road dating back to Jomon and Yayoi periods.
Now the winding road at the foot of mountains is a silent place, but it has long been a popular road dating back to Jomon and Yayoi periods.
Now the winding road at the foot of mountains is a silent place, but it has long been a popular road dating back to Jomon and Yayoi periods.

sen.j: また、飛鳥、藤原の時代には、この海石榴市が栄えていた。
sen.e: The periods of Asuka and Fujiwara saw the prosperity of the Tsubaichi market place.
The periods of Asuka and Fujiwara saw the prosperity of the Tsubaichi market place.
The periods of Asuka and Fujiwara saw the prosperity of the Tsubaichi market place.
